Award.AwardTitle: Identification of molecular mechanisms regulating skeletal morphology
Award.AbstractNarration: The vertebrate skeleton provides a variety of important functions including form, strength, flexibility, and protection of vital organs. Establishment of the complex form of the skeleton requires the coordination of growth with the differentiation of bone-forming cells and joint-forming cells. Indeed, much is known about how cells divide and about how relevant cell types differentiate. However, very little is understood about how these events are coordinated to give rise to skeletal elements of the correct size and shape. The gap junction protein Cx43 has been shown to regulate both cell proliferation and joint formation during zebrafish fin regeneration, revealing that Cx43 coordinates growth and patterning concomitantly. To determine how Cx43 mediates these activities, putative target genes were identified using a molecular genetics approach. Validated Cx43-dependent genes from this list of target genes will be placed in an ordered pathway of genes acting downstream of Cx43. Thus, it will be possible to reveal the step-wise molecular pathway(s) regulated by Cx43 during growth and patterning of the fin. The intellectual merit of this proposal is that mechanistic insights into the establishment of skeletal form and patterning will be revealed. Validation of the top 50 target genes will be completed in part during a new inquiry-based laboratory course for undergraduates. Thus, the broader impacts of this proposal include providing a large number of students access to the practice of science while also providing a set of core laboratory skills in Developmental Biology. The intellectual merit and the broader impacts are fully integrated in this proposal, both advancing the field of knowledge of skeletal morphogenesis and providing instruction on how to solve complex biological problems in a laboratory setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vertebrate skeleton consists of bones of various sizes and shapes, which is responsible for establishing the correct form of animals. Appropriate bone size and shape are the result of temporally and spatially integrated cellular activities, such as cell proliferation and cellular differentiation. However, the molecular mechanisms that coordinate diverse cellular functions are largely unknown.

Using the regenerating zebrafish fin skeleton as a model system, we found that the gap junction protein, Connexin43 (Cx43), acts as a “dial” in regulating the length of the bony fin ray segments. Loss-of-function mutations in cx43 lead to reduced fin growth and premature joint formation (i.e. short segments), while increased Cx43 activity causes increased fin growth and stochastic joint failure (i.e. overlong segments on average). We suggest that Cx43 activity regulates cell proliferation with joint formation in order to precisely coordinate skeletal growth and patterning in the fin. In order to reveal how Cx43 mediates cell proliferation and joint formation in the fin skeleton, we identified a set of genes that function in response to Cx43 activity. The underlying goal of this proposal was to reveal the molecular pathway(s) that are activated as a result of Cx43 function. These are the primary candidates for pathways that contribute to the regulation of cell proliferation and joint formation. The intellectual merit of the award is that completion of this project will identify previously unknown mechanisms for how skeletal growth and skeletal patterning are coordinated, giving rise to bones of the appropriate size and shape. The broader impacts were to include a large number of undergraduates in the research, in the form of a new inquiry-based “Method in Developmental Biology” lab course that has now been added to Lehigh’s Biology curriculum.

The outcomes from this award are that we have now established a group of genes whose functions appear to be regulated by Cx43 activity. During the two years of the funding period that the Methods lab course was run, 20 students participated, 24 genes were tested, and 8 genes were validated. In total, between my research lab and the lab course, 21 of the candidate genes initially suggested to act downstream of Cx43 were validated. Remarkably, 10 of these validated genes function in the extracellular environment. The extracellular environment provides information to cells that influences cellular behaviors. For example, softer environments favor cell division and cell migration.

Our in-depth examination of three of the validated genes revealed the significance of protein and carbohydrate components of the extracellular matrix (ECM, a complex network that surrounds all cells) in communicating with both dividing cells, as well as cells that will differentiate to synthesize bone (these are called osteoblasts). Because a common ECM connects these two different groups of cells, their behaviors may be coordinately regulated. For example, we and others have shown that the ECM transitions to softer materials during the process of regeneration. The softer components are believed to facilitate cell migration and cell proliferation, two behaviors essential to outgrowth and patterning. Our research identified two specific components of the ECM that contribute to coordinating bone growth and skeletal patterning.
